Hammer

Hammer — an important bottoming candlestick line. The hammer and the hanging man are both the same line, that is a small real body (green or red) at the top of the session\'s range and a very long lower shadow with little or no upper shadow. When this line appears during a downtrend it becomes a bullish hammer. For a classic hammer, the lower shadow should be at least twice the height of the real body.

Hanging man

Hanging man — an important top reversal. The hanging man and the hammer are both the same type of candlestick line (i.e, a small real body (green or red), with little or no upper shadow, at the top of the session\'s range and a very long lower shadow). But when this line appears during an uptrend, it becomes a bearish hanging man. It signals the market has become vulnerable, but there should be bearish confirmation the next session (i.e., a red candlestick session with a lower close or a weaker opening) to signal a top. In principle, the hanging man\'s lower shadow should be two or three times the height of the real body.

Bullish engulfing

Bullish engulfing — pattern is comprised of a large green real body which engulfs a small red real body in a downtrend. The bullish engulfing pattern is an important bottom reversal.

Bearish engulfing

Bearish engulfing — a major top reversal pattern, occurs when selling pressure overwhelms buying pressure as reflected by a long red real body engulfing a small green real body in an uptrend.

Dark cloud cover

Dark-cloud cover — a bearish reversal signal. In an uptrend a long green candlestick is followed by a red candlestick that opens above the prior green candlestick\'s high. It then closes well into the green candlestick\'s real body.

Piercing pattern

Piercing pattern — a bottom reversal signal. In a downtrend, a long red candlestick is followed by a gap lower during the next session. This session finishes as a strong green candlestick which closes rnove than halfway into the prior red candlestick\'s real body. Compare to the on-neck line, the in-neck line, and the thrusting line.

Morning star

Morning star — a major bottom reversal pattern formed by three candlesticks. The first is a long red real body, the second is a small real body (green or red) which gaps lower to form a star, the third is a green candlestick that closes well into the first session\'s red real body.

Evening star

Evening star — a major top reversal pattern formed by three candlesticks. The first is a tall green real body, the second is a small real body (green or red) which gaps higher to form a star, the third is a red candlestick which closes well into the first session\'s green real body.

Abandoned baby

Abandoned baby — a very rare major top or bottom reversal signal. It is comprised of a doji star which gaps away (including shadows) from the prior and following session\'s candlesticks.

The same as a Western island top or bottom in which the island session is also a doji.

Advance block

Advance block — a variation on three green soldiers in which the last two soldiers (i.e., green real bodies) display weakening upside drive. This weakness could be in the form of tall upper shadows or progressively smaller real bodies. It signifies a diminution of buying force or an increase in selling pressure.

Belt-hold line

Belt-hold line — there are bullish and bearish belt holds. A bullish belt hold is a tall green candlestick that opens on its low. It is also called a green opening shaven bottom. At a low price area, this is a bullish signal. A bearish belt hold is a long red candlestick which opens on its high. Also referred to as a red opening shaven head. At a high price level, it is considered bearish.

Harami

Harami — a two candlestick pattern in which a small real body holds within the prior session\'s unusually large real body. The harami implies the immediately preceding trend is concluded and that the bulls and bears are now in a state of truce.

The color of the second real body can be green or red. Most often the second real body is the opposite color of the first real body.

Harami cross

Harami cross — a harami with a doji on the second session instead of a small real body. An important top (bottom) reversal signal especially after a tall green (red) candlestick line.

It is also called a petrifying pattern.

Inverted hammer

Inverted hammer — following a downtrend, this is a candlestick line that has a long upper shadow and a small real body at the lower end of the session. There should be no, or very little, lower shadow. It has the same shape as the bearish shooting star, but when this line occurs in a downtrend, it is a bullish bottom reversal signal with confirmation the next session (i.e., a green candlestick with a higher close or a higher opening).

Mat-hold pattern

Mat-hold pattern — a bullish continuation pattern. A green candlestick is followed by a small red real body which gaps higher. Then there are two small red candlesticks which are followed by a strong green candlestick (or a candlestick which gaps open above the last red candlestick).

One-neck line

On-neck line — a red candlestick in a downtrend is followed by a small green candlestick whose close is near the low of the session of the red candlestick. It is a bearish continuation pattern. The market should continue to move lower after the green candlestick\'s low is broken. Compare to an in-neck line, a thrusting line, and a piercing pattern.

Shooting star

Shooting star — a candlestick with a long upper shadow with little, or no lower shadow, and a small real body near the lows of the session that arises after an uptrend. It is a bearish candlestick signal in an uptrend.

Stalled pattern

Stalled pattern — a small green real body which is either above the prior stalled Pattern long green real body or near its top. Sometimes there is a short green candlestick before the lone green one. At the emergence of the stalled pattern, the market\'s rally should stall. Also called a deliberation pattern.

Tasuki gaps

Tasuki gaps — there are downside and upside tasuki gaps. The downside tasuki gap is formed when, in a declining market, a red real body gaps lower. This candlestick is followed by a green candlestick, of about the same size, which opens in the red session\'s real body and then closes above the red\'s real body. It is a bearish continuation pattern.

The upside tasuki gap is a bullish continuation pattern. It is formed when a green candlestick which gaps higher is followed by a red candlestick of about the same size which opens within the green real body and closes under the green\'s real body. Tasuki gaps are rare.

Three crows

Three crows — three relatively long consecutive red candlesticks which close near or on their lows. A top reversal at a high price level or after an extended rally.

Three methods

Three methods — there are two types. The first is the falling three methods which is a bearish continuation pattern. It is comprised of five lines. A long red real body is followed by three small, usually green, real bodies which hold within the first session\'s range. Then a red candlestick closes at a new low for the move.

The second is the rising three methods which is a bullish continuation pattern. A tall green candlestick preceded three small, usually red, real bodies that hold within the green candlestick\'s range. The fifth line of this pattern is a strong green candlestick that closes at a new high for the move.

Window

Window — the same as a Western gap. Windows are continuation patterns. When the market rallies and opens a window, there should be a pullback to that window. The window should be support.

The window should be support. If a window opens in a selloff, there should be a rally to the window. The window should be resistance. The Japanese expression is that "the market goes to the window."
